prompt_init: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story:
The winner of a Xiangqi, or Chinese chess, tournament has been stripped of his title after allegations of inappropriate behaviour.

Yan Chenglong has also been accused of cheating by using a communication device analogous to anal beads.

The 48-year-old has been stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

However, the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) says it's impossible to prove accusations of cheating.

Xiangqi has been hugely popular across Asia for hundreds of years.

According to the CXA, Mr Yan started drinking with friends in his hotel room shortly after winning the title of "Xiangqi King" at a national tournament held on the Chinese island of Hainan last week.

He then defecated in the hotel bath in an act "that damaged hotel property and violated public order and good morals", said the CXA statement.

The CXA was forced to address rumours circulating online that Mr Yan had cheated using anal beads equipped with wireless transmitters to send and receive signals.

"Based on our understanding of the situation, it is currently impossible to prove that Yan engaged in cheating via 'anal beads' as speculated on social media," the CXA said.

As punishment for bad behaviour, Mr Yan was stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

The association did not disclose the amount of prize money Yan was forfeiting, but Xiangqi tournaments often promise winners tens of thousands of yuan (thousands of dollars), according to AFP.
stories:
A Chinese chess champion has been stripped of his title and banned from competition for a year due to allegations of inappropriate conduct.

Yan Chenglong, 48, was accused of cheating by using a device similar to anal beads to receive signals, but the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) said it couldn't prove the claims.

The CXA took action against Yan after he engaged in disruptive behavior in his hotel room, including defecating in the bathtub, which damaged property and violated public morals.

Although online rumors suggested Yan used cheating devices, the CXA stated that it couldn't confirm these allegations.

As a result of his misconduct, Yan was stripped of his "Xiangqi King" title and banned from playing for a year, forfeiting his prize money, which can amount to tens of thousands of yuan (thousands of dollars) in Xiangqi tournaments.

A renowned Chinese chess player has been penalized with a one-year competition ban and stripped of his championship title due to allegations of unacceptable behavior. 

Yan Chenglong, 48, faced accusations of cheating by using a signaling device, but the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) was unable to substantiate these claims. 

Instead, the CXA took disciplinary action against Yan due to his disruptive conduct in his hotel room, including causing property damage and violating social norms by defecating in the bathtub. 

Despite online speculation about cheating devices, the CXA could not verify these allegations. 

As a consequence of his misconduct, Yan lost his "Xiangqi King" title and is prohibited from competing for a year, resulting in the forfeiture of potential prize money amounting to thousands of dollars in Xiangqi tournaments.

A well-known Chinese chess champion has been banned from competition for a year and stripped of his title due to allegations of inappropriate conduct. 

Yan Chenglong, 48, was accused of cheating by using a signaling device, but an investigation by the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) found no evidence to support these claims. 

Instead, the CXA disciplined Yan for his unruly behavior in his hotel room, which included damaging property and engaging in unacceptable behavior such as defecating in the bathtub. 

Although online rumors suggested that Yan used cheating devices, the CXA was unable to confirm these allegations. 

As a result of his misconduct, Yan has lost his "Xiangqi King" title and is barred from competing for a year, which means he will forfeit thousands of dollars in potential prize money from Xiangqi tournaments.

A prominent Chinese chess player has been suspended from competing for a year and had his championship title revoked due to allegations of misconduct. 

Yan Chenglong, 48, faced accusations of cheating by using a signaling device, but an investigation by the Chinese Xiangqi Association found no evidence to substantiate these claims. 

Instead, the CXA penalized Yan for his disruptive behavior in his hotel room, including property damage and unacceptable actions such as defecating in the bathtub. 

Despite online speculation suggesting that Yan used cheating devices, the CXA was unable to verify these allegations. 

As a consequence of his misbehavior, Yan has lost his prestigious "Xiangqi King" title and is banned from competing for a year, resulting in the forfeiture of thousands of dollars in potential prize money from upcoming Xiangqi tournaments.

A renowned Chinese chess master has been banned from competition for a year and stripped of his championship title due to misconduct allegations. Yan Chenglong, 48, was accused of cheating using a signaling device, but an investigation by the Chinese Xiangqi Association did not find sufficient evidence to support these claims. However, the CXA penalized Yan for his unruly behavior in his hotel room, including damaging property and engaging in unacceptable acts such as defecating in the bathtub. Although online speculation suggested Yan used cheating devices, the CXA could not confirm these allegations. As a result of his misbehavior, Yan has lost his esteemed "Xiangqi King" title and is barred from competing for a year, forfeiting thousands of dollars in potential prize money from upcoming tournaments.

Yan Chenglong, 48, faced accusations of using a signaling device to cheat, but an investigation by the Chinese Xiangqi Association found no conclusive evidence to back up these claims. As a consequence of his misbehavior, Yan has lost his prestigious "Xiangqi King" title and is prohibited from competing for a year, resulting in the loss of thousands of dollars in potential prize money from upcoming events.
